articles.headline: Putin Once Tried to Curb North Korea’s Nuclear Program. That’s Now Over.
articles.snippet: Vladimir Putin promised unspecified technological help to North Korea, which could allow it to advance its nuclear weapons program.
articles.abstract: Vladimir Putin promised unspecified technological help to North Korea, which could allow it to advance its nuclear weapons program.
articles.lead_paragraph: As Vladimir V. Putin’s Russia and Xi Jinping’s China deepened their confrontation with the West over the past decade, they were always united with the United States on at least one geopolitical project: dismantling or at least containing North Korea’s nuclear arsenal.

articles.headline: Louisiana Requires All Public Classrooms to Display Ten Commandments
articles.snippet: A law signed by Gov. Jeff Landry on Wednesday makes the state the only one with such a mandate. Critics have vowed to mount a constitutional challenge.
articles.abstract: A law signed by Gov. Jeff Landry on Wednesday makes the state the only one with such a mandate. Critics have vowed to mount a constitutional challenge.
articles.lead_paragraph: Gov. Jeff Landry signed legislation on Wednesday requiring the display of the Ten Commandments in every public classroom in Louisiana, making the state the only one with such a mandate and reigniting the debate over how porous the boundary between church and state should be.

articles.headline: How Two Beluga Whales Made It to Safety From Ukraine
articles.snippet: A pair of  whales were extricated from the besieged city of Kharkiv and taken to an aquarium in Spain with help from experts around the world.
articles.abstract: A pair of  whales were extricated from the besieged city of Kharkiv and taken to an aquarium in Spain with help from experts around the world.
articles.lead_paragraph: It was a whale of an evacuation. Actually, two.
articles.byline: By Marc Santora and Emily Anthes

articles.headline: Spicy Noodles and Pickled Fish: Chinese Eateries Move Into Hong Kong
articles.snippet: As the cultural lines between Hong Kong and China blur, restaurants from the mainland are finding opportunities in the city. But not everyone is happy.
articles.abstract: As the cultural lines between Hong Kong and China blur, restaurants from the mainland are finding opportunities in the city. But not everyone is happy.
articles.lead_paragraph: The ravenous came for a taste of home in a dish of spicy fried beef or steamed fish head. Waiters, speaking in Mandarin, delivered plates heated with green and red chiles.
articles.byline: By Alexandra Stevenson and Zixu Wang

articles.headline: Dilemma on Wall Street: Short-Term Gain or Climate Benefit?
articles.snippet: Portfolio managers have conflicting incentives as the economic and financial risks from climate change become more apparent but remain imprecise.
articles.abstract: Portfolio managers have conflicting incentives as the economic and financial risks from climate change become more apparent but remain imprecise.
articles.lead_paragraph: A team of economists recently analyzed 20 years of peer-reviewed research on the social cost of carbon, an estimate of the damage from climate change. They concluded that the average cost, adjusted for improved methods, is substantially higher than even the U.S. government’s most up-to-date figure.

articles.headline: When the Only Escape From War in Gaza Is to Buy a Way Out
articles.snippet: For many Palestinians, securing approval to exit the territory is possible only after raising thousands of dollars to pay middlemen or an Egyptian company.
articles.abstract: For many Palestinians, securing approval to exit the territory is possible only after raising thousands of dollars to pay middlemen or an Egyptian company.
articles.lead_paragraph: The only way for almost all people in Gaza to escape the horrors of the war between Israel and Hamas is by leaving through neighboring Egypt.

articles.headline: Netanyahu’s Growing Rift With Israel’s Military Raises Questions About Gaza War’s Future
articles.snippet: Their tensions, which have grown quietly for months, reached a new peak this week when the military’s chief spokesman, Rear Adm. Daniel Hagari, made unusually blunt comments.
articles.abstract: Their tensions, which have grown quietly for months, reached a new peak this week when the military’s chief spokesman, Rear Adm. Daniel Hagari, made unusually blunt comments.
articles.lead_paragraph: Growing divisions between Israel’s military commanders and the civilian government over the war in Gaza spilled into the open this week, raising questions about how Israel will conduct the next phase of the war.
